summary_reasoning: The report states most key drivers near the forecasts they inform, with numerical targets for NIM, NII growth, efficiency ratio, noninterest revenue CAGR, cost of equity, Stage II growth, and share count, so explicitness is reasonable. Specificity is solid: magnitudes, units, and timeframes (e.g., 2025–2027 NIM, 10-year noninterest revenue CAGR, and share count trajectory) are generally clear and tied to model tables. Justification is partial: some assumptions reference business context (asset cap removal, asset sensitivity, deposit franchise) and macro rate paths, but many core parameters (e.g., 2.5% fee CAGR, 3% Stage II net income growth, 9% COE) lack supporting evidence from multi-year history, peer benchmarks, or cited sources. Internal consistency has a notable numeric contradiction between narrative NIM (compression to ~2.70% in 2025 and 2.66% in 2026) and the model table showing 2.8% (2025) and 2.7% (2026). Stress-testing is limited; while there is a quantified sector bear-case (midteens FVE decrease) in an archived note, there are no company-specific sensitivities quantifying valuation impacts across major levers (rates/NIM, credit cost, efficiency). Overall, explicit and specific inputs with a clean model layout, but modest justification and a text–table inconsistency constrain the grade.

assumptions_extracted.quote: expect net interest margin, or NIM, to compress slightly to around 2.70% in 2025 ... NIM of 2.66% in 2026.
Overall, NIM compression and modest growth in loan and deposit balances lead to a NII growth of about 1% in 2025.
we project the federal-funds rate to reach 2.50% by the end of 2027.
Overall, we project a 2.5% noninterest revenue compounded annual growth rate in the next 10 years.
the bank will eventually bring its efficiency ratio back down to roughly 61%
